config.question: How was the role of women in 1920s society impacted by the industrial revolution?

choices.content: More women had returned to the home by the end of the decade due to dissatisfaction with factory and office work.
The status of women deteriorated as gender divisions between men and women were exaggerated by industrialization.
The number of working women increased marginally, but overall the role of women in society did not change.
Women gained equal opportunity in all sectors due to the huge number of jobs created by industrialization.

answer_2.response: Consider This: Although World War I accelerated the process by which women left the home for work, the postwar decade witnessed a return to the slower pace of the prewar years. Women had won the right to vote in 1920, but the Nineteenth Amendment had less impact than its proponents had hoped. Adoption of the amendment robbed women of a unifying cause, and the exercise of the franchise itself did little to change sex roles. See L.O. 25.2 How did life in the cities change after World War I?
